Halloween Insomniac Tour
The Baltimore Rent-a-Tour will sponsor a Halloween Insomniac Tour, one of three Insomniac Tours a year, Halloween
night from 1:30 a.m. to sunrise for people of any age.
The tour will include a tour of Westminster Graveyard and
be highlighted by a magic show. The cost is $27.50 per person.
Those wishing to take the tour must make reservations
before Saturday. The tour starts at the Inner Harbor at 1:30.
For more information, call Ruth Vader at 653-2998.

Homewood Halloween Party
The Greater Homewood Association is holding a Halloween party tomorrow night at St. John's Church at the corner of
27th and St. Paul Streets.
The event, hosted by the Homewood Consumer Corporation and the Baltimore Housing Alliance, will last from 9 p.m. to
1 a.m. Music will be provided by Style 11. Tickets cost $3.50 if
bought in advance, and $4.00 at the door. Those attending must
wear a costume.
For more information, call the Greater Homewood
Association at 889-7927.

Marion House To Open
The Marion House, a residence and employment training
program for women who want to lead independent lives, will
open March 1, 1982. The house is located at St. Bernard's
Church on 949 Gorsuch Ave., and the director is Sister Marilyn
Graf, R.S.N.
Any woman 18 or over who feels a need to better herself
educationally or wants training for a permanent job may enter
this program. There is no phone at St. Bernard's yet, but more
information can be obtained by calling Sister Marilyn at

SC Lobbies Against
Plus/Minus Grading
BY LINDA MCINTYRE
Since last week's referendum vote on plus/minus grading,
many students have been wondering what the next step will
be. The Student Council is
currently working out its strategy for the next phase in the
debate.
According to Student Council president Chuck Peifer, the
overwhelming "no" vote in last
week's balloting served to firm
up the Council's position on the
issue. "The vote last week
rubber-stamped our position on
the issue," he said. "We have
decided to officially oppose the
plus/minus grading system."
President Steven Muller in
an address to freshmen Wednesday night said that he felt
plus/minus grading would be "a
great disservice to undergraduates." He added, however, that
he is unable to do much to
change the policy; that, he said,
is up to the Academic Council.

Peifer, along with Education
Doug
Committee Chairman
Fellman, plans to visit members
of the Academic Council, the
group of faculty members elected by their peers, who initiated
the proposal, to discuss their
position on the matter. Some of
the members have already talked
with Peifer and Fellman and,
according to Fellman, "the faculty is being very receptive to
student input."
The Student Council also
hopes to be put on the agenda
for the next Academic Council
meeting, which will be held
sometime next month.
As it stands now, it no
change is made in the current
Academic Council policy the
grading system will change to a
plus/minus system in September
1982. Although there would be
an A+, it would be an honorary
grade appearing only on transcripts. For purposes of the
GPA, the A+ would count as
4.0.

a private security agency. It would seem,

violence should be reducing the size of the
crowd.

means changing the nature of the enterprise, and this brings us to the next problem inherent in the present scope of the

One day of rain and a truckful of melted
ice cream, and the finances of this or that
student group go down the tubes. Too
much is riding on the Fair. and the circumstances of the Fair cannot be counted on to
support the weight. To answer the question
raised above, the Fair should be fun, first
and foremost, and not a commercial
boondoggle that can backfire in everyone's
face.

should be limited to Hopkins students, or
made into some sort of innocuous bazaar:
but it should be geared to the enjoyment of
the students, and eliminating rock music
runs directly counter to that purpose. If
the Fair were less of a commercial enterprise, crowd sizes would be smaller, and
then there would be no need to eliminate
rock 'n' roll . There would be less financial.
risk all around, and everyone just might
have a better time.

expect the Fair to be scaled down this year,

urge the committee, then, to reconsider the
compromise position that it rejected before
banning rock music during the day. At least
some rock could be played during the day,

BY GEORGE YATCHISIN
Punk is dead. The word is out
around England, even though youths are
rioting just like the Clash said a few years
ago. The new "in" fashion is the Blitz.
The trendsetters of what's hip have given
up on the doom and gloom forecast of
punk, simply because it was too damn
depressing. Why wear ripped t-shirts and
put safety pins through myself if nobody
really cares? Violence may be the answer, but I don't enjoy getting beaten to
a bloody pulp. So why not celebrate?
Dress up, pretend everything's alright.
It's surely not a better solution, but it is
infinitely more fun.
The Blitz is having fun. Taking its
name from the London club where the
fad began, the Blitz is not only lifestyle
and fashion, but more importantly,
music. It has defined the elusive "new
romantic" movement. David Bowie is the
superhero of the Blitz as he is the king of
dressing up. His poses are both famous
and infamous, but that's what a Blitz kid
wants to be. Garish, gaudy, wearing
make-up. Brocaded, ruffled, silk slicked.
Life is a ball.
But back to the important thing —
the music. The Blitz's roots lie deep in
Eurodisco (what else?), for if you can't
dance to it it really doesn't matter. In a
typical Blitz club one would hear, lots of
Bowie, old Roxy Music, practically
anything associated with the Glitter
Movement.
There are new groups too, not to
mention a few who converted to the
Blitz's bouncy beat. Perhaps the musical
leader of this new New Wave is Steve
Strange, a founder of the early Blitz clubs
and of Visage, one of the original Blitz
groups. To typify the essence of the
movement, Strange arrived at his first
U.S. press conference riding a camel.
Like I said, these people mean to have
fun.
Clearly, there is an air of irresponsibility that underlies this fad. At times
this notion sneaks into the music — it
might sound good, you might want to

move your finely tailored outfit to it on
the dance floor, but it gets awfully insipid
on the home stereo. The Blitz lads don't
care — this is social music — but then
again, the only group to put out two
"official" Blitz albums so far, Ultravox,
got a little more dark and serious the
second time out. Maybe the immature
will grow up.
A sampling of Blitz albums:
Adam and the Ants. Kings of the
Wild Frontier. What can one say about
Adam Ant? He's already a cult figure of
sorts for mixing American Indian and
pirate influences to create music powered
by two drummers(this is the only similarity to the Doobies). All of the songs
here don't really fit the Blitz, but one
wouldn't want them to. It's a horribly
produced album and beyond "Dog Eat
Dog" and "Los Rancheros" there isn't

much to listen to. (I know — Antmusic"
is an anthem, but that fails to make it
good.) However, the group does the
fashion of the Blitz to the hilt, and gets
points for publicizing the fad in the first
place.

and an instrumental, "623," that sounds
even better at 45 r.p.m.

Repulsion

Cracked Woman Staring At Cracks
BY WALTER HOOK
This Sunday, Repulsion, directed
by Roman Polanski, will be playing in the
Reel World. The film will be a treat for all
of you who enjoy feeling alienated.
Repulsion opens with lengthy
scenes of Catherine Deneuve, a beautiful
blonde woman, walking home from the
beauty parlor where she works. She looks
nervous and uncomfortable when construction workers whistle and jeer at her.
Then Polanski lets us see her take most of
her clothes off, wash her legs, and lie on
her bed — scenes which Polanski no
doubt enjoyed shooting. An unknown
man has fallen in love with her, and after
managing to land a date, tries to kiss her.
The look on our heroine's face tells the
story: repulsion.
Male viewers, like the unknown
suitor, have been seduced by Deneuve's,
looks. But at least some of us have doubts
about the woman's mental capacity. We
often find her staring in revulsion at

Y-shaped cracks. When her sister leaves
on vacation with her boyfriend, our
heroine begins to cook a rabbit, and after
setting it on the coffee table, she forgets
all about it. The rotting carcass ornaments her living room for the rest of the
film.
The more our heroine puts off her
suitor, the more he's convinced of his
undying love for her. As in E.T.A. Hoffman's "The Sandman," we begin to
wonder if the woman isn't an automaton.
The only personality this woman seems
to have is her revulsion for men, and the
pressure the predatory suitor puts on this
automaton seems to be making it malfunction. She stops going to work, chops
up her phone cord, and boards up her
front door. Meanwhile, the rabbit is still
rotting. As the decaying dinner seems to
represent her own mental decay, the walls
of her apartment, which begin surrealistically cracking, not only symbolize her
crack, but her cracking up. Then imaginary suitors being raping her, and as her

repulsion for men grows, so does her
madness.
The film is simultaneously witty
and chilling, making the male viewer
wince at his own ability to be seduced by
such an automaton. (There is a theory
that since most beautiful women are
repulsed by aggressive suitors such as
Roman Polanski, he portrays this repulsion as a form of mental illness to soothe
his bruised ego. This is simply untenable.) The emphasis on close-ups creates a
very claustrophobic atmosphere, and the
numerous scenes shot in all-white rooms
give the film a dehumanized quality.
Though the acting is solid, particularly
Deneuve's thoroughly convincing portrayal of the dumb blonde, the pacing of
the film is painfully slow. Despite the
cleverness of the film's concepts, too
often I found myself bored. The film is
very rewarding intellectually, but its
claustrophobic, dehumanizing atmosphere and slow pacing make it uncomfortable to sit through.

There are many ways you
can reduce the strain of academic life at Johns Hopkins: attend
a movie, participate in off-campus activities, or go around
killing people. The last is just
a game, of course, sponsored by
HopSFA every year. It is called
the Killer Game, and the president, John Harkness, a former
player, and Laury Hott, a
student at Hopkins, are running
the unusual game this year. The
game began this week, with
about 35 people participating.
Students from all classes
may take part in the contest,
which consists of chosen "killers" shooting their assigned
"victims" with rubber-tipped
dart guns. The killer is assigned
one victim at first, and if he kills
his victim within two weeks, he
is immediately given another.
This goes on until all of the
killers, of which there can be
any number, kill their victims —
and each other — and there is
only one person left ... the
winner. This winner's prize is
the satisfaction of knowing he
killed everyone.
The other
players gain some satisfaction,
too, of having fun and temporarily turning their minds away
from schoolwork.
According to Hott, the
game from last year is still going
on, though it was only supposed
to last for two weeks. Her
reason for this is that it went
fast at first, and then "it got
sneaky." This was true for all
three of the previous games(two
official games and one unofficial
one).
Some of the victims
became
especially
cautious
aboia killers — they made sure
they had many friends with
them at all times, among other
things.

Could this mean that the
game is taken too seriously by
the players? A few think so.
Hott had a visiting roommate
last year who thought that the
game was being carried too far
by extremely enthusiastic participants. But evidently, almost
everyone else feels differently,
for the whole senior class played
last year. A former student of
Hopkins said it is a great game
which "keeps people out of
trouble." He has played in all
the previous contests.
Like other games. Killer has
its rules. First of all, there can
only be one witness when
you kill someone or are killed,
so you can't jump up in the
middle of class and aim your
dart gun at your victim. Aiming
brings about another rule: no
head shots. If you are caught
shooting someone in the head
area two times, you are out of
the game. No other weapon can
be used but a dart gun or rifle
with rubber-tipped darts, The
victim is not to be informed of
his killer: he will know in time,
because before he can shoot, the

murderer must say, "I am
your killer.- But there are two
chances for the victim to escape
death.
After the murderer
has announced his identity, the
victim has the opportunity to
shoot his killer if his killer
is too slow to fire the dart gun.
Also, the killer and victim
may sign a truce, agreeing not to
murder each other. This isn't
much of a relief, though, for if
one leaves the other's sight for
five minutes, the truce is off.
You may kill as many
victims as you are assigned, but
you cannot have a roommate for
a killer or a victim. And each
killing must be written out with
both the killer's and the victim's
signatures. So the game is not as
easy as it sounds.
The only problem, according to Hott, occurs when students who do not live on or near
the campus want to be in the
game. "Then they have to make
special trips to the campus to
kill someone," she explained.
Other than that, the Killer Game
runs without major mishap each
year.

But It So Happens We Like It
The Spring Fair Committee's decision to ban rock music from the Fair
during the daytime seems, at first glance,
arbitrary and insensitive to the wishes of
the students. Most of us like rock and roll
- it seems to have gained something of a
following over the last few decades.
But the committee's decision, howunpopular
it may prove, was not a
ever
kneejerk reaction. There have been an
increasing number of violent incidents at
the Fair during the last few years. A
lengthy report by the committee documents the opinions of a number of knowledgeable people (including Major Robert
Larkin, Chief of Security) that the elimination of rock music would substantially
reduce the potential for violence at the
Fair.
So, keeping in mind that the committee is not a group of Montiverdi-loving
nerds, we must look at the larger issue that
they themselves addressed in making their
decision: namely, what is the purpose of
the Fair? Is it to make money or to have
fun? Fun, of course; and it should be
possible to have fun, safely, without
banning the devil rock 'n' roll.
Look at it this way: the Fair is
perhaps the major non-academic event of
the year. Within a space of three days,
something close to 150,000 people come
tromping across the Homewood campus.
The money they spend makes possible
some of the most attractive features of the
Fair. such as the big-name performers like
Martin Mull; it makes up a large part of
many student activity group budgets: and it
contributes several thousand dollars to the
SAC emergency fund.
An event of this magnitude is bound
have
problems on the same scale. First
to
is that the Campus Security
list
the
on
police, no matter how dedicated and
competent they may be, numbers only 14.
This is less than one one-hundredth of a
percent of the size of the crowd they have

to deal with over the three-day period. The
Administration has indicated that it would
sooner cancel the Fair than bring in Baltimore City police, and Security Chief
Larkin says that coordination problems
would rule out hiring additional men from
a private security agency. It would seem,
then, that the first priority in reducing
violence should be reducing the size of the
crowd.
Of course, reducing crowd size
means changing the nature of the enterprise, and this brings us to the next problem inherent in the present scope of the
Fair: it's too risky, and last year proved it.
One day of rain and a truckful of melted
ice cream, and the finances of this or that
student group go down the tubes. Too
much is riding on the Fair. and the circumstances of the Fair cannot be counted on to
support the weight. To answer the question
raised above, the Fair should be fun, first
and foremost, and not a commercial
boondoggle that can backfire in everyone's
face.
This is not to say that the Fair can or
should be limited to Hopkins students, or
made into some sort of innocuous bazaar:
but it should be geared to the enjoyment of
the students, and eliminating rock music

risk all around, and everyone just might

compromise position that it rejected before
banning rock music during the day. At least

each set. But don't take it all away. It's
only rock 'n' roll, but we like it...

Waters' Celluloid Sleaze
BY DOREEN MORAN
Passing by the Charles Theatre
one night in early May, I noticed an
unusually large crowd gathered on the
sidewalk beneath its brightly lit marquee.
The large black letters proclaimed: "World.
Premiere — Polyester," and 1 naively
wondered who would name a film Polyester? Little did I know, John Waters was
back in town.
For the film-goer who has experienced John Waters' previous endeavors,
Polyester is no surprise. In fact, one
wonders if he hasn't gone a bit slack in
the passing years (his last film, Desperate
Living, premiered in 1977), for Polyester
lacks the extreme gore and violence of
Multiple Maniacs, Pink Flamingos, and
Female Trouble (1970, 1972 and 1974
respectively). However, for those who
have never even heard of Waters, and who
may be drawn to the new film via his
"scent-sational" promotional gimmick
"Odorama," numerous reactions are
possible, the most prevalent being disgust.
Perhaps I should explain.
John Waters is a weird guy. Even
weird for Baltimore. What some might
call a by-product of Charm City, Waters
delights in the bizarre, the sleazy, the
decayed. As he says in the first line of his
autobiography, Shock Value, "To me,
bad taste is what entertainment is all
about." This probably accounts for the
numbers of people who walk out after

the first twenty minutes of the movie,
and for those who, after the first showing, disgustedly comment to the people
waiting on line for the second, "Don't
bother. It's really gross."
Waters' characters are obese
women who go shopping with their hair
up in bright pink curlers; men who wear
loud checked blazers with striped pants;
adolescents who unnerve their parents

Cracked Woman Staring At Cracks
BY WALTER HOOK
This Sunday, Repulsion, directed
by Roman Polanski, will be playing in the
Reel World. The film will be a treat for all
of you who enjoy feeling alienated.
Repulsion opens with lengthy
scenes of Catherine Deneuve, a beautiful
blonde woman, walking home from the
beauty parlor where she works. She looks
nervous and uncomfortable when construction workers whistle and jeer at her.
Then Polanski lets us see her take most of
her clothes off, wash her legs, and lie on
her bed — scenes which Polanski no
doubt enjoyed shooting. An unknown
man has fallen in love with her, and after
managing to land a date, tries to kiss her.
The look on our heroine's face tells the
story: repulsion.
Male viewers, like the unknown
suitor, have been seduced by Deneuve's,
looks. But at least some of us have doubts
about the woman's mental capacity. We
often find her staring in revulsion at

Y-shaped cracks. When her sister leaves
on vacation with her boyfriend, our
heroine begins to cook a rabbit, and after
setting it on the coffee table, she forgets
all about it. The rotting carcass ornaments her living room for the rest of the
film.
The more our heroine puts off her
suitor, the more he's convinced of his
undying love for her. As in E.T.A. Hoffman's "The Sandman," we begin to
wonder if the woman isn't an automaton.
The only personality this woman seems
to have is her revulsion for men, and the
pressure the predatory suitor puts on this
automaton seems to be making it malfunction. She stops going to work, chops
up her phone cord, and boards up her
front door. Meanwhile, the rabbit is still
rotting. As the decaying dinner seems to
represent her own mental decay, the walls
of her apartment, which begin surrealistically cracking, not only symbolize her
crack, but her cracking up. Then imaginary suitors being raping her, and as her

repulsion for men grows, so does her
madness.
The film is simultaneously witty
and chilling, making the male viewer
wince at his own ability to be seduced by
such an automaton. (There is a theory
that since most beautiful women are
repulsed by aggressive suitors such as
Roman Polanski, he portrays this repulsion as a form of mental illness to soothe
his bruised ego. This is simply untenable.) The emphasis on close-ups creates a
very claustrophobic atmosphere, and the
numerous scenes shot in all-white rooms
give the film a dehumanized quality.
Though the acting is solid, particularly
Deneuve's thoroughly convincing portrayal of the dumb blonde, the pacing of
the film is painfully slow. Despite the
cleverness of the film's concepts, too
often I found myself bored. The film is
very rewarding intellectually, but its
claustrophobic, dehumanizing atmosphere and slow pacing make it uncomfortable to sit through.

Killer Craze Strikes Campus
BY KIM SHEARIN
There are many ways you
can reduce the strain of academic life at Johns Hopkins: attend
a movie, participate in off-campus activities, or go around
killing people. The last is just
a game, of course, sponsored by
HopSFA every year. It is called
the Killer Game, and the president, John Harkness, a former
player, and Laury Hott, a
student at Hopkins, are running
the unusual game this year. The
game began this week, with
about 35 people participating.
Students from all classes
may take part in the contest,
which consists of chosen "killers" shooting their assigned
"victims" with rubber-tipped
dart guns. The killer is assigned
one victim at first, and if he kills
his victim within two weeks, he
is immediately given another.
This goes on until all of the
killers, of which there can be
any number, kill their victims —
and each other — and there is
only one person left ... the
winner. This winner's prize is
the satisfaction of knowing he
killed everyone.
The other
players gain some satisfaction,
too, of having fun and temporarily turning their minds away
from schoolwork.
According to Hott, the
game from last year is still going
on, though it was only supposed
to last for two weeks. Her
reason for this is that it went
fast at first, and then "it got
sneaky." This was true for all
three of the previous games(two
official games and one unofficial
one).
Some of the victims
became
especially
cautious
aboia killers — they made sure
they had many friends with
them at all times, among other
things.

Could this mean that the
game is taken too seriously by
the players? A few think so.
Hott had a visiting roommate
last year who thought that the
game was being carried too far
by extremely enthusiastic participants. But evidently, almost
everyone else feels differently,
for the whole senior class played
last year. A former student of
Hopkins said it is a great game
which "keeps people out of
trouble." He has played in all
the previous contests.
Like other games. Killer has
its rules. First of all, there can
only be one witness when
you kill someone or are killed,
so you can't jump up in the
middle of class and aim your
dart gun at your victim. Aiming
brings about another rule: no
head shots. If you are caught
shooting someone in the head
area two times, you are out of
the game. No other weapon can
be used but a dart gun or rifle
with rubber-tipped darts, The
victim is not to be informed of
his killer: he will know in time,
because before he can shoot, the

murderer must say, "I am
your killer.- But there are two
chances for the victim to escape
death.
After the murderer
has announced his identity, the
victim has the opportunity to
shoot his killer if his killer
is too slow to fire the dart gun.
Also, the killer and victim
may sign a truce, agreeing not to
murder each other. This isn't
much of a relief, though, for if
one leaves the other's sight for
five minutes, the truce is off.
You may kill as many
victims as you are assigned, but
you cannot have a roommate for
a killer or a victim. And each
killing must be written out with
both the killer's and the victim's
signatures. So the game is not as
easy as it sounds.
The only problem, according to Hott, occurs when students who do not live on or near
the campus want to be in the
game. "Then they have to make
special trips to the campus to
kill someone," she explained.
Other than that, the Killer Game
runs without major mishap each
year.
